title: british ministers coronavirus china lab leak theory
story: BRITISH ministers are “no longer discounting” the theory that coronavirus originated after leaking from a Chinese bio research lab in Wuhan, according to reports.Senior sources have reportedly admitted while the “balance of scientic advice” is that the virus originated naturally, a leak is also being considered by security services.Theories about the origins of coronavirus being linked to a lab in Wuhan have been batted around since the early days out of the outbreak.One member of Cobra, the emergency committee led by Prime Minister Boris Johnson, said security services are now considering a possible leak, reports The Mail on Sunday.The source added however they did not dispute the virus was “zoonotic” - meaning it originated in animals.Chinese officials have previously attempted to dismiss claims of a leak as internet rumours.The government source’s comments come as pressure ratchets up on China to come clean over the outbreak.More than . million people have been infected worldwide, and almost , people have been killed during the pandemic.The member of Cobra, which receives classied briefings from British intelligence, said: “There is a credible alternative view [to the zoonotic theory] based on the nature of the virus.“Perhaps it is no coincidence that there is that laboratory in Wuhan. It is not discounted.”Downing Street has said it “does not recognise” the claims made by the source.Some unfounded conspiracy theories circulated worldwide have claimed coronavirus is a kind of man-made bioweapon, but there is no evidence of this.Wuhan is home to the Institute of Virology, the most advanced laboratory of its type in mainland China.The £million institute is just ten miles from the wildle market which is believed to have been at the centre of the outbreak.Scientists at the institute were the first to link the new coronavirus to bats.The state-run People’s Daily newspaper also boasted in  that the lab was capable of conducting experiments with “highly pathogenic microorganisms”.Unveried local claims have suggested workers at the lab became infected after being sprayed with blood, and then carried in infection into the local population.The city also has a second lab - the Wuhan Centre for Disease Control , which is just three miles from the market - which is also believed to have carried out virus experiments on animals.Video emerged last week of a Chinese scientist catching bats for viral experimentation at the WCDC.The conventional wisdom is however still that the virus passed from bats to another animal and then to humans at one of Wuhan’s so-called wet markets.Following the coronavirus outbreak, China has issued new laws that call for facilities to ensure “biological safety” and improve management of viruses.A leak from a Chinese lab led to an outbreak of Sars that killed one person and infected nine others in .The Chinese government admitted the leak was down to negligence and that five officials were punished.China has been accused of attempting to cover-up the initial outbreak as the virus took hold in the city of Wuhan.A doctor who first warned about the virus was threatened by police, and then last month Chinese officials suggested the US military may have been responsible for coronavirus.China now claims it has weathered the virus storm, and yesterday mourned victims with a three minute silence as it positions itself as a world leader amid the pandemic.In a letter to the Mail on Sunday responding claims China would face a “reckoning” from Britain over the outbreak, the Chinese embassy hit back - but declined comment on the lab origin theories.Chinese embassy official Zen Rong said: “Such reports completely disregard the tremendous efforts and huge sacrice of China and its people, and deny Chinas signicant contribution to global public health and safety.“China wasted no time in identying the viruss pathogen, sharing the genetic sequence with the World Health Organisation, taking the most effective, strict and comprehensive measures to contain the spread of the disease, sharing experience with other countries in need, and providing assistance to more than  countries, including the UK, and to four international organisations.”In a statement, an embassy spokesman added: “There has been no scientic or medical conclusion yet on the origin of Covid-, as relevant tracing work is still underway.“The WHO has made repeated statements that what the world is experiencing now is a global phenomenon, the source is undetermined, the focus should be on containment and any stigmatizing language referring to certain places must be avoided.”Questions loom large of the origins of the outbreak, and whether or not the Communist Party have been truthful over their death toll.Biosecurity researcher Richard Ebright, a professor at the Waksman Institute of Microbiology, said the coronavirus behind the pandemic was . per cent similar to a bat virus discovered by the Wuhan Institute of Virology in  and studied at the WCDC.He said: “Bat coronaviruses are collected and studied by laboratories in multiple parts of China — including Wuhan Municipal CDC and Wuhan Institute of Virology.Therefore, the first human infection also could have occurred as a laboratory accident.China’s top virologist on bat-borne viruses, Shi Zhengli, has sworn on her le that virus did not leak from her lab in Wuhan.She blamed the virus has being spread by “nature punishing the human race for keeping uncivilized living habits”.The researcher has told those claiming the virus came from her lab to “shut their stinking mouths”.But she previously admitted she had “lost sleep” fearing the virus may have leaked from the research facility.Politicians in both the United Kingdom and United States have previously urged China to be more open about what it knows about the coronavirus.Writing in thelast month, Tobias Ellwood, chairman of the defence select committee called from greater transparency from China.Mr Ellwood, a former captain in the British Army, said it would “irresponsible” to outright blame the Chinese military – but said his job requires he understands “threats facing the UK”.He wrote: “I would like to know more about the Chinese army’s [lab], coincidentally located a stones throw from where the latest outbreak began.”He added: “Successive US administrations have long believed that a number of countries, including China, maintain active biological programmes.“But without greater Chinese transparency we cannot be completely sure. China’s immediate response to the outbreak in Wuhan was to squash the story.“The Chinese doctor who first raised the alarm was obliged publicly retract his comments and charged with ‘rumour mongering’.”US senator Tom Cotton also suggested that the virus may have come from a research lab and also called for transparency from China.On Wednesday, he told the Daily Caller : The reason I have raised these questions from the very beginning is because of China’s statements and their actions“After concealing the virus for many weeks in December and then minimizing its severity for most of January, they then peddle an origin story about the food market in Wuhan.”“Given their dishonesty and the proximity of these labs, which we know were working with coronaviruses, it is only reasonable and responsible for us to ask the question and demand the answers.”US President Donald Trump has even raised questions over Chinas official account with regards to the death toll - but has also praised their handling over the outbreak.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealUS congressman Michael McCaul accused China of the “one of the worst cover-ups in human history” last month while speaking on Fox News.He accused the Communist Party of a “systematic whitewash” and called for an international investigation to “hold the Chinese government to account”.Mr McCaul, a Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said: “Now we have a global pandemic that originated out of Wuhan.“They allowed millions of people to come to Wuhan to celebrate their Spring festival.“Five million of them leading the area and traveling domestically and abroad – they went into laboratories and shut them down – destroyed laboratory samples and they detained eight of the doctors trying to speak the truth about what really happened in Wuhan.”In a statement, the Wuhan Institute of Virology said the conspiracy reports had “received close attention from all walks of le” and “caused great harm to our research staff on the front line of scientic research” back in FebruaryLab chiefs said staff had been working around the clock since the end of  to trace the source of the coronavirus and improve detection rates - adding the theories seriously interfered with their efforts.Despite the speculation however, the World Health Organisation praised China and President Xi Jinping for their handling of Covid- back in February.WHO director Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said: “The logic doesn’t support the idea [of a cover up]. It’s wrong to jump to conclusions.”He added: Nobody knows for surethey were hiding [anything].Half the world’s population are now in lockdown as governments attempt to slow the spread of the virus.Britain yesterday suffered its deadliest day as  were confirmed dead - raising the total to ,.And as the UK bathes in sunshine this weekend sparking fears of the virus spreading, The Queen is due to address the nation tonight at pm.ltgtOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus nurses ppe
story: Dr Rinesh Parmar, of the Doctors Association, said there are still major issues surrounding the lack of personal protective equipment .He told the Sophy Ridge On Sunday show that NHS staff are having to reuse eye masks and added that some nurses doing high-risk procedures are having to hold their breath.Dr Parmar added that a survey conducted by his organisation has found that almost half of doctors say they have no eye protection at all.He said he had also heard from doctors who said they have been forces to reuses masks and they should be single use only.He added: Nurses are doing some of these high risk procedures because theyre unsure whether the masks theyve been provided with is going to offer them adequate protection.He said: Sadly doctors have been forced to take matters into their own hands.Asked on whether the NHS would cope, he said: Weve gone into this pandemic in a position of relative weakness.Dr Parmar said that along with the safety of patients, the safety of the workforce is our paramount concern.He said: Given the severe lack of PPE getting through, we are all very concerned about potentially losing more colleagues.Dr Parmar said it was sad to hear of those who had already been lost in the line of duty, adding none of us wants to hear further stories of frontline staff losing their lives.As the coronavirus crisis worsens in the UK, doctors and nurses have spoken out about the lack of personal protection equipment for hospital staff.Some members are said to have bought scrubs on Amazon or had friends knit them protective kit.Dr Samantha Batt-Rawden, from Doctors Association UK, said: At a time when the country is relying on frontline NHS staff, this is unforgivable.It comes as The Sun has launched the Who Cares Win appeal to give all NHS frontline staff help they desperately require during this unprecedented crisis - title: britain only stopped a third of infected people spreading coronavirus
story: Professor Neil Ferguson said today that Public Health England were unable to prevent two thirds of people from spreading the disease when they came back from hotspots around the world.The number of deaths rose by  yesterday - the highest amount since the crisis began - but those are likely to have been people who were infected weeks ago.Professor Ferguson hoped that the number of deaths could be slowed to between , and , thanks to the lockdown measures, which started on March .Flights were never completely stopped from China and Italy during the early stages of the pandemic, meaning people were able to come in with no checks.People continued to come into the country and were only told they must isolatethey develop symptoms.It compares to other countries like New Zealand and China - who forced people to isolate for  days when they entered the country, or who checked the temperatures of everyone coming in.Professor Ferguson told the BBCs Andrew Marr Show this morning: What happened in this epidemic is that people flew into this country with infections, seeding the infectionPublic Health England, the Health Authorities did their best to intercept such people and isolate them.But we think probably only about one third of infected people were stopped. And so we seeded infection in dferent areas across the country.Some counties, like northern Italy, were very unlucky and clearly go community transmission starting very early. Here it started a little bit later.Professor Ferguson - who has been helping advise the Government on what measures are needed to tackle the virus - also revealed that HALF of people in intensive care units were now Covid- patients.But he said that at the moment the NHS is coping and will hopefully continue to cope with an increase in cases.The peak will come in the next seven to ten days before plateauing and hopefully starting to decrease, he confirmed.That could be on Easter Sunday, the Health Secretary said last week.But any lockdown measures are not likely to be lted until after case numbers start to go down, Prof Ferguson said.There is no point having gone through this effort and releasing the lockdown at a point where case numbers are still high and then will surge even faster than we’ve seen before, he added.We want case numbers to get to a low point where we can start substituting other measures for the most intrusive and economically costly aspects of the current lockdown. title: why is keir starmer sir knighthood
story: Heres everything you need to know.The labour leaders official title is Sir Keir Starmer, but he prefers people not to use it.He told the Ham  High newspaper that he has never liked titles.He said: When I was DPP, everyone called me director and I said, Please dont call me director, call me Keir Starmer. Its a very similar battle now.He is a sir because of his knighthood, which he received for services to law and criminal justice.Keir Starmer was knighted in .At the time he had just stepped down as head of the Crown Prosecution Serviceand Director of Public Prosecutionsby the Attorney General.The DPP is the head of the CPS - meaning Mr Starmer was responsible for some , staff and an estimated , prosecutions each year.He held the role for five years, between  and .According to the Independent, all of Starmers predecessors in the role were also awarded knighthoods.Mr Starmer was knighted for services to law and criminal justice.Throughout his illustrious law career he worked on a number of huge cases, including the successful retrial of Steven Lawrences killers and the prosecution of a metropolitan police officer following the death of newspaper vendor Ian Tomlinson.As well as these, he prosecuted Energy Secretary Chris Huhne and his former we, Vicky Pryce fro perverting the course of justice.Huhne was the first politician in British history to resign over criminal charges.The self-described socialist also worked to abolish the death penalty in several Caribbean countries.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: free school meals during holidays too
story: Usually parents dont get extra help with food during the holidays, but ministers have u-turned on the rules thanks to the ongoing coronavirus crisis.Micheal Gove said yesterday: For children eligible for free school meals, vouchers will be available through the holidays to support household income.He added that more news was to come on this.Campaigners including celebrity chef Jamie Oliver and headteachers had called for all kids to get extra help during the holidays too.He has said: “Now more than ever we need to make it as easy as possible for parents and carers to feed their kids well.”Stephen Tierney, chairman of the Heads Roundtable, which represents head teachers, welcomed the news.He said: The announcement by Michael Gove is really welcome. Without this thousands of children were likely to go hungry over the Easter break.We hope the government will now consider making vouchers available every holiday for the poorest families.The vouchers, worth £ a week per child, can be spent on food at supermarkets including Sainsbury’s, Tesco, Asda, Morrisons, Waitrose and MS.Parents need to apply directly to their childs school to receive the additional help - its then up to the school to decide whether theyll get vouchers or meals.If the school is giving out vouchers, these can be emailed or posted to parents.Its not yet clear whether said.Last week the Government and BBC announced a partnership for  weeks of lessons on the telly - in a hint that schools would be shut for the entire of the next term as well.Gavin Williamson has title: brits ignore coronavirus lockdown sunbathe drink
story: Many were seen enjoying beers outside and sun bathing on the hottest day of year so far - things the government has said is not considered an essential reason to leave the house.Health Secretary Matt Hancock this morning warned a total ban on outdoor exercise could come into forcepeople continue to ignore the lockdown measures.Police were seen speaking to groups of people flouting social distancing measures on Primrose Hill in London this morning.Sun bathers were also seen getting a warning from officers as many hoped to take advantage of this weekends warm temperatures.A group title: footballers should donate wages to hospices
story: Matt Hancock said that people should stop rowing and come together in this time of crisis.He told ITV News this lunchtime that the public would support such a move. title: vladimir putin self isolating coronavirus russia
story: VLADIMIR Putin is understood the be self-isolating as he works remotely and cuts down social contact following a coronavirus scare. Russias strongman leader shook hands with a doctor last week while visiting a hospital in Moscow, only for the medic to later be confirmed to have coronavirus.Putins office confirmed he was taking precautions in the week, but today his spokesman said the president is likely to remain avoiding personal contact and working from home for at least the next seven days.Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov told state-run TV: A week has passed I dare to suggest that Putin will work remotely for another week, or even longer.I think that the case with the chief Kommunarka physician falling ill has demonstrated that, despite all precautions, the best and only effective measure is to reduce physical contacts, and that is exactly what the president did.Mr Peskov was speaking on the Moscow. Kremlin. Putin weekly show on television channel Rossiya-.It comes as Russia faces a coronavirus outbreak, as cases rose by  yesterday to over , - with Moscow being the epicentre.At least  people have been killed by the virus in the country, which has now infected more than .million people worldwide.Russia ordered a nationwide lockdown for the month of April last week following Putins own coronavirus scare.Kremlin officials have insisted however everything is fine and there was no reason to worry about the -year-old Putins health.Putin is understood to be staying at his Novo-Ogaryovo residence near Moscow.Putin made a highly public visit to the Kommunarka hospital on March  -  days ago - in which he met Dr Denis Protsenko.The Russian leader inspected the hospital in a brightly coloured hazmat suit, but spoke to the medic without any protective gear.He also was pictured shaking hands with him without gloves.Days later Dr Potsenko tested positive for the coronavirus, but insisted he felt quite well.He said he had self-isolated in his office were he would continue to work.Doctors have urged people to self isolatethey come into contact with someone who has coronavirus.It is designed to help control the spread of the disease as symptoms can sometimes take two weeks to appear - yet the virus can still be passed on.Conspiracy theories emerged last week that all was not well with Putin after state-TV broadcast old footage of him attending meetings - with some saying he had disappeared.Ilya Shepelin, a journalist with independent news channel TV Rain, speculated that Putin may be in self-isolation.Chief hospital nurse Lyudmila Larionova said she was shaken by Putin’s decision to enter the coronavirus wing which was treating  victims.The Russian president and the country’s elite have been accused of believing themselves to be immune from the virus.Putin’s spokesman Mr Peskov defended his visit to the hospital last week.He said: He always prefers to see with his own eyes how things are going on the frontline.Putin would not be Putinhe did not decide to go there.The Russian president held a government meeting by video-link last Wednesday.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers.The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM.No matter how little you can spare, please donate today herewww.thesun whocareswinsappealRussian lawmakers voted to give the government powers to declare a national emergency over the coronavirus.The measures include penalties for violations of lockdown rules including, in extreme cases, jail terms of up to seven years.It comes as Russia sent a military plane carrying  tons of coronavirus aid to the US on Wednesday.Mr Peskov said: “Trump gratefully accepted this humanitarian aid.Half the world is now on lockdown due to the coronavirus, which has infected all be  countries.The global death toll has surpassed , and fears loom it could wipe .trillion off the global economy.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: how to watch queens speech live
story: Heres how to watch her speech live.Her Majestys speech was broadcast on all major broadcasters tonight at pm.The speech also aired on ious radio stations, as well as live-streamed on social media.The best bet is to check on BBC iPlayeryou dont get a chance to watch it live.Alternatively you can follow The Suns live blog.In a rare speech, the Queen thanked Brits for following government rules to stay at home and praised those “coming together to help others”.She also thanked key workers, saying “every hour” of work” brings us closer to ato more normal times”.“While we have faced challenges before, this one is dferent,” the Queen said.“This time we join with all nations across the globe in a common endeavour, using the great advances of science and our instinctive compassion to heal. title: queens speech 2020 when else addressed nation

title: icu nurse pleads public stay inside coronavirus
story: Shirley Watts, an operating theatre nurse at Basildon University Hospital in Essex, said she wanted people to see the reality of whats going on describing the situation as desperate and short staffed.Speaking to the camera after finishing a sht, Shirley says: Things are pretty desperate .... were all having a really hard time.She adds: Were desperately short of staff. I want you say you need to stay indoors and you need to stop spreading it, you need to stop catching it.A tearful Shirley adds: Were putting ourselves in danger to save to try and save other peoples loved ones.It feels like a losing battle, but its not because weve all got hope and were all trying to do what we can.Shirley made the tearful plea after finishing a six hour sht and told viewers she was going home to sleep before ing for another sht tonight.Posting to Facebook, she wrote: I thought long and hard about sharing this, butit makes one person stop and think about going out unnecessarily then I’m happy for you to see me like this ... tired, tearful, sinking but not broken. Britain is heading into a third week of lockdown as the coronavirus death toll rises to , today after  more people died.A total of , across the UK have now tested positive for coronavirus.Fewer deaths were announced today than the  yesterday or the  on Friday.But the number of new daily infections jumped - title: who keir starmer new labour leader
story: Heres everything we know about the former shadow Brexit secretary.Keir Starmer is a barrister and politician from London.He was a human rights lawyer before becoming an MP, and co-founded The MP owns at least  per cent of a company investing in businesses hit by falling share values. Somerset Capital Management says investors have a “once in a generation” chance of “super normal s”. Mr Rees-Mogg stood down as a director of SCM to become Leader of the House of Commons. SCM said it was focusing on clients’ long-term security. It came as the UK death toll rose by a record  – including a boy aged five. As millions face financial misery, SCM managers are buying into businesses where valuations have tumbled – but should bounce back. Potential gains of  per cent are touted. Investments so far include private hospitals in Brazil, pharmacies in South Africa and a firm behind a scanning device which checkspeople are wearing masks in China. The revelation was greeted with dismay by new Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer, who said: “Nobody should be seeking to take advantage of this crisis. We should all be asking ourselves what we can do for our country and each other.”Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell added: “This is about as sick as it comes. Profit seeking from suffering is nearly as low as you can get. When we come through this we need a tax on profiteers.” SCM’s strategy comes amid a crisis that has killed , globally, while a further ,, are infected. The UK death toll yesterday rose  to ,. Some , have tested positive. While the economic impact has seen almost a million Brits sign up for Universal Credit, finance houses have been quick to move. Mr Rees-Mogg, , stood down as a director of SCM so he could become Leader of the Commons last July. But he owns at least  per cent, meaning he was entitled to a reported £million share of last year’s £.million profits.Father-of-six Mr Rees-Mogg, who lives in a mansion in Somerset, is reportedly worth more than £million. That could risea plan by SCM’s Emerging Markets Discovery Fund pays off. Fund boss Mark Asquith said in promotional material that investors could capitalise on smaller companies in particular, with prices down up to  per cent. He wrote: “History has shown us that super normal s can be made during this type of environment. Market dislocations of this magnitude happen rarely, perhaps once or twice in a generation, and have historically provided excellent entry points for investors.”  Mr Asquith cited  per cent profits made after the  crisis and suggested “we could see similar moves”. SCM, which has a £.billion portfolio of client funds, is so keen to attract investors it has waived a .% management fee. Giving examples where they hope to profit, Mr Asquith’s co-manager Christopher White identied Hapvida, a Brazilian medical insurance company which also runs hospitals. It has a deal to care for patients in the public health system. Stock has also been bought in Clicks, South Africa’s leading pharmacy. SCM is also invested in Advantech – behind technology rolled out in China to monitor mask wearing and temperatures of people in public places. SCM was co-founded by Mr Rees-Mogg in . His office declined to comment last night.  The firm is managed in part via the tax haven of Singapore. In November the Sunday Mirror revealed SCM traded shares in a firm fined for its role in the  Deepwater Horizon oil spill disaster. It also had holdings of £million in a Russian bank suspected of helping the annexation of Crimea and pro-Putin terrorists in the Ukraine.

title: keir starmer appoints rival lisa
story: NewsKeir Starmer appoints rival Lisa Nandy to top job as he unveils new Labour shadow cabinetThe new Labour leader has reshuffled the partys top team as he starts to make his mark. Out are Corbyn loyalists to be replaced by those on the soft left. Its a big role for Lisa Nandy but the runner-up in the race Rebecca Long-Bailey has been snubbedShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsKeir Starmer is trying to put his stamp on the Labour Party " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKeir Starmer appoints leadership rival Lisa Nandy to top job but snubbed Rebecca Long-Bailey. It is a huge promotion for Ms Nandy who came third in the contest but had a good campaign securing more votes than expected. But Long-Bailey, who came second in the race and was widely-dubbed the Corbyn continuity candidate, did not get one of the top roles. Ms Nandy said in response: “It’s a real honour to be tasked with leading Labour’s foreign policy response in these dficult times. Thank you Keir Starmer for the opportunity to serve.” The new party boss made Anneliese Dodds Shadow Chancellor - a huge promotion for the former MEP who is widely-liked by the parliamentary Labour Party - and Nick Thomas-Symonds replaced Diane Abbott as Shadow Home Secretary.Angela Rayner, who won the deputy leadership contest, was made party chairwoman, while Jon Ashworth remains Shadow Health Secretary.Rachel Reeves, who was Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary under Ed Miliband, was given a job shadowing Michael Gove. The MPs form Labouraposs C- Committee, responsible for coordinating the party’s response to the coronavirus crisis.Mr Starmer said: “We are living through a national emergency. “Under my leadership, the Labour Party will always act in the country’s interest to save lives and protect livelihoods. “That will be the number one priority of my Shadow Cabinet. “We will be a responsible opposition that supports the Government where we believe they are right and challenge them when we believe mistakes are being made.” Mr Thomas-Symonds, a Welsh barrister, said he was “honoured” at his appointment. He added: “The immediate task is to focus on the #coronaviruscrisis: as @Keir_Starmer said this morning, we will work constructively with the Government, not scoring political points, but also asking the dficult questions needed.” Ms Reeves posted: “It is a huge honour to be appointed byto be shadow chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, shadowing the Cabinet Office. I look forward to working with Keir and Team @UKLabour as we provide a constructive opposition at this incredibly dficult time for our country.” Mr Starmer wielded the kne on his first full day as party premier, ousting frontbenchers who were close to Mr Corbyn. Barry Gardiner, who was fired as Shadow International Trade Secretary, tweeted: “Just received a courteous phone call from Keir Starmer standing me down from Shadow Cabinet. “I wished him and his new team well.I will continue to do all I can to serve the party and ensure a Labour victory at the next General Election.Jon Trickett was sacked as Shadow Cabinet Office Minister. The MP for Hemsworth, West Yorks, tweeted: “Keir has politely asked me to stand down from Shadow Cabinet. “I reaffirm my commitment to the cause of working class emancipation and to the North. “The struggle continues.” Key Corbyn loyalist Ian Lavery was sacked as party chairman, saying: “It has been an absolute honour and privilege to have been chair of this great party. “Solidarity to the new leadership and incoming Shadow Cabinet.” But Mr Starmer opted to keep on Nick Brown as Chief Whip, and Baroness Angela Smith will remain as Labouraposs leader in the House of Lords. Other Shadow Cabinet posts are expected to be announced on Monday. The radical shake-up was widely-tipped as Mr Starmer used his landslide victory to assert his authority and clear out those most associated with the Corbyn regime.  He secured % of the , votes cast in the three-month contest - beating his rivals Rebecca Long-Bailey and Ms Nandy tin the race for the party reins. The new leader told BBC Oneaposs The Andrew Marr Show the Shadow Cabinet would be “balanced across the party, it will be balanced across the country and balanced in terms of ersity”. Asked“Blairites” would feature, he said: “We arenapost badging people by the past, we are focused on how we win the  general election.” The team would be packed with “those that want to serve towards the future aim of winning that next general election”, he added. Mr Corbyn had issued a defiant valedictory message to supporters before stepping down, claiming he had left the party in a position to win the  election. But Mr Starmer said: Weaposve just lost four elections in a row, and therefore of course we need to change becausewe donapost change we will lose the next general election. He said he would judge his success at tackling anti-Semitism within Labour ranks by whether Jewish supporters rejoin.  He said: I will judge it not in numbers but aposDo people feel comfortable coming back to our party apos and other people who have felt they canapost support us - so that will be my test.

I will have in my shadow cabinet those that want to serve towards the future aim of winning that next general election, he told BBC Oneaposs The Andrew Marr Show. It will be a talented, balanced shadow cabinet.:Thats it - for nowKeir Starmer has announced the names for the main roles within the shadow cabinet but there are plenty more places to fill. Tomorrow we#xre expecting to hear more. Keep an eye on Rebecca Long-Bailey - Keir#xs rival for the top job. Discipline may be less of a problem going forward but it#xs always helpful to have someone who knows how to #xCwhip#xD the votesneeded.Shadow Chief Whip Nick Brown :Jonathan Ashworth keeps healthApart from an awkward slip up when he was caught on tape criticising Jeremy Corbyn during the election, Ashworth has by all accounts done a good job at health. He#xs been a fairly solid performer both in parliament and in the media and has proved himself during the coronavirus pandemic. It certainly seems logical to keep him in place at the moment. Matt Hancock has praised his opposite number and even admitted changing government policy because of Ashworth#xs scrutiny. He is a close ally of Angela Rayner and would probably be classed as soft left.Jonathan Ashworth, the Shadow Secretary of State for Health :Rachel Reeves becomes Shadow Chancellor of the Duchy of LancasterSeen as on the right of the party, Reeves is popular with MPs and many have called for her to have a big role. Starmer plumping for the more left wing Dodds as Shadow Chancellor but still keeping Reeves in a big role suggests he is trying to reach out across the party. It will take someone with Reeve#xs experienceto face Michael Gove at the despatch box. :Home Secretary to Nick Thomas-SymondsBig boost for Thomas-Symonds who has been a quietly confident player as shadow secretary general and had gone head-to-head with ebullient Tory Geoffrey Cox. He said he was #xChonoured#xD by the appointment. The lawyer said in a tweet that the #xCimmediate task is to focus on the coronavirus crisis#xD and promised to #xCwork constructively with the Government, not scoring political points, but also asking the dficult questions needed#xD.Home Secretary Priti Patel responded to him saying: #xCMany congratulations to Nick on being appointed as Shadow Home Secretary. I hope we can work together at this time of critical national importance - I have asked my team to get touch.#xDNick Thomas-Symonds :Lisa Nandy becomes Foreign SecretaryIt is always regarded as the job you give to your biggest rival. See Barack Obama to Hilary Clinton, Gordon Brown to David Miliband - in theory so they can spend most of their time out of the country, although not so much in the shadow cabinet. title: now not time discuss pay
story: NewsNow is not the time to discuss pay rise for nurses, says Matt HancockThe Health Secretary said he was "sympathetic to the argument" as nurses battle to keep patients safe from coronavirusShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR NewsNHS nurses " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Matt Hancock has said now is not the time to discuss a pay rise for nurses, although he said he was sympathetic to the argument.The Health Secretary paid tribute to the work being done by those in the health service but would not be drawn on whether they deserved more money. The starting salary for a nurse will be £, in  . Nurses suffered like the rest of the public sector from the coalition then Tory governmentaposs pay freeze with lasted from - and then % pay cap for the next five years. They finally secured a pay rise in  with a rise of .% agreed. But may say it is a paltry amount compared to the work they do. Nursing has lagged behind other NHS staff groups over the past decade, with the workforce growing by just .% between November  and November , compared with .% for hospital doctors, for example. On Friday chief nurse Ruth May paid tribute to two of her colleagues Aimee OaposRourke, , and Areema Nasreen, , who died from coronavirus after treating patients and warned that there were likely to be more.Presenter Andrew Marr told Mr Hancock nurses are paid around £, a year at the moment, asking the Health Secretary: do you think as a result of this experience they deserve to be paid more in the future He replied: Well, look, everybody wants to support our nurses right now and I’m sure that there will be a time to debate things like that.At the moment the thing that we’re working on is how to get through this. And so you know I’m very sympathetic to that argument, but now is not the moment to enter into a pay negotiation. Now is the moment for everybody to be doing their very best. But appearing on the same programme, the new Labour leader Keir Starmer insisted that the NHS needed more money and that many of those who have been vital during the crisis deserve to be paid much better.He said the pandemic had exposed who the key workers really are and they very often have been overlooked, underpaid and there’s going to be a change. They were last and now they’ve got to be first. He added that the NHS desperately needed more investment. He said: We’ve got to look at funding. The NHS has struggled for funding over the last ten years, so that’s got to be looked at and we have to think about how we reimagine the economy going forward.Mr Starmer warned against responding to the huge public spending to tackle coronavirus with another decade of devastating austerity.We don’t know what the final figures will be but what we can’t do is simply make the mistake that we made in  and go for another decade of austerity. We’ve seen what that has done to the country, we cannot go down that route. The new Labour leader said we canapost go back to business as usual after the pandemic.He said: I think it is inevitable that we have to ask those that have more to pay more.The truth is at the moment we don’t yet know how big this challenge is going to be until we’re through this crisis, but when we are through there’s going to have to be a reckoning. We’re going to have to do things dferently. We’re going to have to build a better future.

title: voice mirror fatcats tories dont
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Fatcats and Tories don’t know value of our real heroesThe willingness of NHS staff to cobble kit together from whatever they can find is inspiring, because it shows what can be achieved in adversity - but it is also shaming, because as a rich, industrialised nation we should have done more for themShareCommentsByVoice of the Mirror:,  APR NewsopinionDr Alfa Saadu did not need to work, but he did not hesitate to join , retired NHS workers on the coronavirus frontline " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDr Alfa Saadu did not need to work. But he did not hesitate to join , retired NHS workers on the coronavirus frontline. After  years saving lives, Dr Saadu, , lost his own last week at London’s Whittington Hospital after contracting Covid-. The surgeon’s son described his dad as a “living legend”. And that is true of all those putting their lives on the line to tend to the sick and dying. All are living legends. They battle an invisible invader with too little testing of their own health and not enough personal protection equipment to keep them safe. Their willingness to cobble together kit from whatever they can find is inspiring, shaming and humbling in equal measure. Inspiring, because it shows what can be achieved in adversity. Shaming, because, as a rich nation, we should have done more for them. Humbling, because they carry on regardless. Dr Saadu was not the first medic to die of this nasty, creeping disease. And tragically he will not be the last. Behind doctors, nurses and paramedics, a whole army of NHS workers are also toiling round the clock. The hospital porters, cleaners and caterers, the drivers, the volunteers, the maintenance and admin staff. Alongside them are the key workers who keep our nation ticking over in these perilous times – the shelf-stackers and shop assistants, the posties, truckers, delivery drivers, refuse collectors and utility workers. And the , selfless helpers who stepped forward to ensure the old and vulnerable are not forgotten. Thursday, pm, is proving itself a moving moment as a grateful nation unites to honour them. We reach out to each other in the only way social distancing allows – by putting our hands together. The response of our country to this calamity has been truly astounding. Even those twiddling their thumbs at home are doing their bit by staying there.  Astounding, too, is the response from Somerset Capital Management, the investment firm founded by House of Commons lounge lizard Jacob Rees-Mogg. While Britain has all eyes on a multiplying virus, these virulent fatcats can see no further than multiplying pound signs. While millions face being struck down by Covid-, SCM delights in a “once in a generation opportunity” to make millions by cashing in on the crisis. If Mr Rees-Mogg had an iota of honour, he would disown these grubby profiteers. A politician of real integrity would now sever his links with the company altogether. He may be worth millions, but in the coronavirus stakes his value falls far short of a doctor or nurse. It is their skill and dedication we rely on now to save our lives. It is their caring and compassion which will comfort those reaching the end of theirs.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailIn her own words, Barbara Currie, now , tells Notebook magazine how she turned to yoga aged , and has never looked back... I am living proof that you’re never too old to do anything. Nor is it ever too late to change your le. I was  years old when I discovered yoga. Before that I’d been living a glamorous le as cabin crew for British Airways. Travel was rare and expensive back in those days, you had to be very wealthy to fly on planes, so it was quite amazing. I loved it. But a rubbish rule back then was that, when you got married, you were no longer eligible for the job. I met my husband three years in and we went on to have two children and moved to Scotland as a family. Well, what a lestyle change! I didn’t know anybody and felt quite lonely with two small kids, so I decided to explore what was going on in the local area. There were two things – curling and yoga. Curling to me looked way too much like sweeping up, so I booked onto yoga, having no idea what it was. When the teacher turned up I was in awe. She was in her early s and just looked fantastic. She was so flexible and could do everything with ease and total vitality. I thought, ‘Whatever she’s doing, it works.’ I was exhausted and stressed with the children and the move when I walked in, but when I left I felt so much lighter. I couldn’t stop thinking about how effortless my teacher made it look. I was hooked. My teacher went on to inspire me, but she was very strict. Posture had to be perfect, she discussed anatomy and physiology with us, and we were expected to really know our stuff. She was an incredible teacher. After a year I decided I wanted to be a yoga teacher. In  I started my three-year course, getting stronger with each session. Now, it wasn’t easy.  I genuinely thought I was quite flexible after all these lovely skiing and surfing lessons I’d been lucky enough to have during my time with BA, but I was stf as a board when I started my training course. Now I know that’s been an advantage in my career –I can do it, anyone can. My first class was a complete accident and I wasn’t prepared. My teacher called in sick and asked me to step in. I managed to do it, but realised how dficult it was to explain things. However, after a while, when I saw some people struggling and I managed to help, I completely forgot about myself. Yoga is absolutely the best thing for your mental health, in my opinion. With all the dismal things going on around us, it teaches us to train our minds and focus on things we are grateful for and practise blue-sky thinking – things that we really want to happen. But it’s also a lot better in terms of physical exercise than people may realise. It tones, it helps joints, it strengthens your bones, helps your breathing, helps your heart and rids you of any tension. Whatever your ailment, I have a pose for it! Oryou want to come to a class and just lie on the mat, that’s fine too. It’s important to give our bodies what they need. Nowadays, yoga is very trendy, but back when I started it was known by so few. My classes became so popular that a journalist from The Daily Mirror called me up and invited me in for an interview on this new ‘craze’ back in .  From that the Mirror asked me to do a fitness video. It sold for £. and sales went through the roof! I couldn’t believe it when I was invited on morning telly to teach live yoga. My whole le changed. I’d be getting my shopping and people would say such nice things. They’d ask, ‘How did you do that one ’ and I’d give a live demonstration in the fruit and veg aisle. People are very kind, aren’t they  So I’m always happy to help. After that I went on to make  videos, which have sold millions worldwide. The most popular was The Age Free Body . I do believe that, as long as you go carefully, youthfulness is an attitude. There is no reason why those in their s and s can’t practise yoga. All you’re doing is gently working on your body and training it to a state of perfect health. It’s also judgement-free exercise, because no matter what level you do, it keeps you healthy, so it doesn’t matter what anybody  thinks. As for me, I practise yoga every day for about an hour by myself, and I am very conscious of my diet. I’ve always been fascinated by nutrition. As a war baby, all we thought about was food. Then everything was rationed until I was about aged seven, so food wasn’t consumed greedily, we just hoped we had enough to eat.  I once saw a doctor who explained that so many people on medication could be helped through pure, natural food and I tried it for a week. I’ve never changed my diet in  years. I eat fresh fruit, fresh vegetables, a little cheese, chicken, fish, milk, but skip all junk. No sweets, cakes, puddings, and instead I just eat fresh beautul food. The only sugar I have now is figs. They are rather lovely and I love a couple after dinner. I even swerve birthday cake. I know it sounds awful to say I haven’t had a slice of cake for  years, but it’s true. It’s not depriving myself, I just love my diet and how it makes me feel. I never drink alcohol. I used to have the odd glass of fizz as cabin crew and hated how it made me feel. But I feel great, quite honestly, and touch wood I’ve never been poorly. That’s not to say that diet goes hand in hand with yoga. People shouldn’t feel miserable about their bodies. You can be bigger and flexible. Often those new to exercise feel scared about taking the first step, but I make them realise that no one is perfect.  It’s lovely seeing clients encouraged when the person next to them can now do a pose they could never do. They’re always happy for each other. I love to help people start feeling proud of themselves again. I live in London with my husband and still teach  times a week. My oldest lady is  and she’s been with me for  years. What a lovely le I’ve been able to have all through my hobby. My family have adapted well to my fame. They see ft cut-outs of me in shops next to my DVDs and say, ‘Hello Mum’. If you’ve never tried yoga, you’ll finish your first class feeling like you’re walking on air. It’s never too late to change your le and you never have to slow down.

story: NewsAutistic girl who only eats Dairylea Dunkers may starve in lockdown, fears mumMum Stacey Smith is facing a "nightmare situation" trying to source enough of the cheesy snack whilst in lockdown and fears supermarkets buying limits could mean her supply runs dryShareCommentsByTom HitchenorSteven Collins:,  APR NewsAlicia-Mae Jones, , who only eats Dairylea Dunkers " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A mum fears her autistic daughter could run out of food during the coronavirus crisis - because she only eats the bread sticks from Dairylea Dunkers.Alicia-Mae Jones, , munches through  packs of the cheesy snack every day and refuses any other food. Mum Stacey Smith, , forks out £ a week - or £, a year - on her daughteraposs habit, which is more than she pays in rent. But she now worried her health could suffer as supermarkets introduce buying limits. Stacey has to rely on friends and family to pick up the £. packs whenever they can as she is self-isolating with Alicia-Mae, who has a range of health problems. She said: “It really is a nightmare situation. At the minute we are okay but itaposs not going to continue forever. We donapost know how long this lockdown is going to be for.  “Thataposs my concern and what I worry about, I need to buy bulk, in case they stop stocking or limit buying further. “On a monthly basis, the price of these Dunkers costs more than my rent. Itaposs £. for a box of four, which she will easily eat before lunch. “You are looking at around  packs a day, at around £-£ a day. Itaposs around £ a week. Itaposs a lot of money and itaposs pretty much the same as my monthly house rent. She only eats the breadstick and not the cheese in each box. “Friends and family, when they go shopping, pick up the two allowed. They try to explain the situation to staff but the supermarkets donapost allow you to get anymore. “People have commented that aposIf she is hungry she will eatapos but she has had a number of health problems since she was born. Alicia-Mae, of Worcester, suffered from gastroschisis at birth - a bowel condition in newborn babies. She was also diagnosed with visual impairment at six-months-old, autism at two and then liquid on the brain at four, which required a shunt to clear the fluid.  It puts her at risk of contracting coronavirus, meaning mum Stacey has to self-isolate to protect her daughter. Stacey, who is separated from Alicia-Maeaposs dad but lives with her partner, added: “Friends and family do go out and try to help us. However, theyaposve got their own kids, so itaposs a case of them grabbing packs whenever they can. “Everybodyaposs in the same situation. Some people arenapost even leaving their house and trying to get deliveries online, so it is really concerning. Full-time mum Stacey said that the issues around Alicia’s eating started at around -months-old when they tried to move her onto solid foods. She said: We were doing the pureed veg when she was a baby, which she was absolutely fine with. “But when we moved onto solids, she started to gag and refused to eat it at weaning age, which is  months. She would even headbutt the wall. “The dietician told us to try dry food and let her feed herself, with the breadsticks being the only thing she stuck too. “For a week or two, she really liked sweet potatoes but then couldnapost eat those.  “Anything and everything we piled on her plate, carrot sticks, vegetables, she wouldnapost have. It would all get thrown to the side. “She doesnapost have crisps, chocolate, cake, ice cream, so itaposs not like she solely eats bad food. “The dietician has said to leave her without food for daysshe refuses to eat anything . She has gone three days without eating before. “She doesnapost eat the cheese so she doesnapost get her calcium fix. People comment on her size, but she has been on steroids for her conditions. “She has vitamin drops so we can keep her healthy. “Her hair, skin, nails are all fine. Alicia is bigger than average, but she has the same condition as Harvey Price. “People can be so ignorant and have been saying nasty things about my child.

story: NewsBargain-hunting mum transforms bathroom for just £ during coronavirus lockdownA woman has revealed how she managed to make over her bathroom for under £ after her partner bet she couldnt do it for less than the cost of a meal out for their familyShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  APR NewsThe whole room cost £ to make over " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWith the vast majority of the UK stuck at home on lockdown, people are looking for creative ways to fill their time. One mum decided to use the days at home as an opportunity to finally decorate the bathroom she hated in her three-bedroom home in Swinton, Greater Manchester. But there was a catch, her partner challenged her to transform the space for under £.Bargin hunter Clare Dore, , accepted the task and has revealed how she managed to do up the bathroom for just £ during the coronavirus lockdown. The savvy mum-of-three bought everything to decorate the room from BM Bargains before social isolation orders came into force earlier this month - painting the walls and tiles and even using gold marker pen to spruce up the grouting.Her partner Tony, , was gobsmacked when he saw the final result. And daughters Sienna, , Destiny, four, and two-year-old Avaya all love the new green and gold-themed space too. Clare said: Before my bathroom was  years old and I hated it. I really wanted to revamp it but we had planned to move house in the next year or so, so Tony said it didnapost make sense to spend the money. I challenged him to let me do itI could do it for less of the cost weaposd spend on a family meal out at the weekend - around £ or £. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK is getting ready to enter its third week in lockdown, with people instructed to stay at home to curb the spread of coronavirus. Despite high visitor numbers to parks and beaches suggesting fatigue may be setting in, Brits have been warned to be ready to hunker down for the long haul, as cases of the deadly bug could keep rising for another two to three weeks. Despite hopes that drastic social distancing measures will soon flatten the curve of the Covid- pandemic, Professor Paul Cosford, Public Health Englandaposs Medical Director, has warned that lockdown measures are nowhere near ending. Other experts, however, such as government adviser Professor Graham Medley of Imperial College London have argued that prolonged periods of lockdown could cause more harm than coronavirus itself, leading to soaring unemployment, food poverty, domestic violence and mental illness. So how long is it likely to last and who will decide when and how to end the restrictions  Follow the latest coronavirus updates here  When will the UK end lockdown  It is not yet clear when the UK will be able to lt its strict social distancing and lockdown measures. Prime Minister Boris Johnson is due to review the measures for the first time next week, however when asked about an exit strategy at the daily press conference on Saturday, Michael Gove said: Thereaposs no fixed point, no specic date in the calendar at which we can say things will change, we are keeping them under review. One key government doctor has said some measures may be in place for up to six months. Dr Jenny Harries, deputy chief medical officer, said of the rules last week: Three weeks for review, two or three months to seeweaposve really squashed it, but three to six months, ideally, but lots of uncertainty in that but then to see at which point we can actually get back to normal and it is plausible it could go further than that. This is not to say we would be in complete lockdown for six months, but as a nation we have to be really, really responsible and keep doing what weaposre all doing until weaposre sure we can gradually start lting ious interventions which are likely to be spaced - based on the science and our data - until we gradually come back to a normal way of living. What needs to happen before the lockdown can end  Ministers and scientists have been reluctant to say what requirements must be met before they relax the rules and are still emphasising the importance of social distancing. Business Secretary Alok Sharma has warned there could be another rise in casesthe measures are lted too quickly. He told a press conference on Wednesday: Whataposs also really important is thatwe stop these too quickly, there is a possibility that that massive effort people have made across the country is wasted and we could potentially see a dangerous second peak. We absolutely want to avoid that. One scientist has suggested that mobile phone data could help lt social distancing quicker by speeding up contact tracing. Prof Martin Hibberd, professor of emerging infectious disease at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: A combination of some social distancing measures, extensive testing and automated contact tracing could allow both a more regular social activity and a signicant control of the outbreak.  Who gets to decide when it ends  The decision to end lockdown in the UK will be made by the Government alongside scientists and doctors. When the measures were put in place last month, the Prime Minister said they would be reviewed every three weeks. Top NHS doctor Professor Stephen Powis said scientists are still focusing on learning how the illness works. He said on Saturday: It is very likely that this virus will become established in populations throughout the world and so we need a strategy to manage this over time, not just in the next few weeks or the next few months. Scientic knowledge about this virus is still being discovered. As we learn more about it, as the scientic evidence builds, that will allow those strategies to evolve. Professor Graham Medley, who is advising the government, has told The Times the shutdown is merely buying time and there is no clear exit strategy from the Covid- crisis. He said: This disease is so nasty that we had to suppress it completely. Then weaposve kind of painted ourselves into a corner, because then the question will be, what do we do now  We will have done three weeks of this lockdown, so thereaposs a big decision coming up on April . In broad terms are we going to continue to harm children to protect vulnerable people, or not

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email An intensive care unit nurse has described the heartbreak he feels at being the only person who can comfort coronavirus patients in their time of need. Jake Savoie shared his thoughts on Facebook alongside a selfie taken while wearing personal protective equipment at work.He said he did not want to write a similar post, but he could not stay quiet after the stretch of nights that I just had at work. The nurse added: Seeing the amount of people who still aren’t taking this seriously is upsetting. The Facebook post reads: In the weeks leading up to this virus finally reaching our area, I read a lot of articles  viral posts warning me of the physical demands that this outbreak would place on me as an ICU nurse. I mentally prepared myself for the layers upon layers of PPE that I would be wearing, the profuse amount of sweating that I would be doing, etc...however, I was not prepared for the intense emotions that I’d be experiencing. He added coronavirus patients have no normal human interaction in the hospital until they finally test negative. Jake said: The PPE you see in my picture is just a glimpse of what a suspected positive COVID patient sees at all hours of the day night whenever ANYONE is required to enter their room . These patients have no normal human interaction from the moment they step inside the hospital until they are officially declared negative, until the virus has run its course, or until they sadly take their last breath. My heart broke more  more each time that I’d walk into a patient’s room and see the fear in their eyes. Think about this the next time you consider going out because you are tired of your only human interaction being through FaceTime or with those in your household. The nurse added a very dficult part of his job is to tell patients sad news - for example when they have to be placed on a ventilator - especially because medical workers are often the only support people who tested positive for the virus have, since their family cannot be close to them. He wrote: Once again, they receive this frightening news ALONE  their only source of comfort emotional support is from myself, another nurse, physician, respiratory therapist, or CNA dressed in full PPE. One of the most dficult things I’ve ever done as a nurse is tell a grown adult with tears in my eyes that the moment they feared most has come - ...very soon you will see me  a doctor enter your room with even more protective gear to place you on a ventilator, but I will be with you the whole time...just pretend that I’m one of your own children holding your hand.  Sharing the emotional thoughts, Jake also urged people to stay at home in order to fight the spread of the virus. He said: Think about this the next time you decide to invite a group of people over because you’re bored  lonely. These patients aren’t the only ones affected during all of this. Their family members are at home constantly wonderingthey’re safe, taken care of, afraid, comfortable... their hair is brushed the way it usually is... they are sleeping with two pillows the way that they usually do... they have someone to pray with before eating supper like they usually do at home. Their nurses doctors RTs CNAs entire care team are feeling defeated because they want so badly to help but we’ve exhausted all treatment options, medications  ventilator settings. Think about this the next time you decide to ignore elected officials’ warnings advisories because “this is all a political stunt”.  My coworkers  I are exhausted, traumatized, and scared, but we are a team of rockstars  we will push through this public heath crisis. We will fight for our patients every single day no matter the circumstance, but please don’t make it harder for us to fight by going places  gathering with other people when it’s NOT essential to do so. Jake concluded: Stay home, encourage your loved ones to to stay home, hold each other accountable, and pray for everyone on the frontlines of this pandemic. Many people shared their appreciation for the work that Jake and all his fellow medical workers are doing during the pandemic. One person commented: Jake, you and your colleagues are all heroes. Thank you for all that you do. Stay safe for your family. Respect.  Another one said: Your words should be read aloud. They bring home the reality of the situation that you  our other NHS health workers face. Iaposm sad that the human race can be so selfish  humbled by so many wonderful things that are happening during these unprecedented times. One person wrote: This made me cry. One of my best friends is a critical care nurse here in the UK, she’s my personal hero. Thank you for everything you and your colleagues are doing, you are all incredibly strong. It comes as the government has urged people to stay indoors and only go outnecessary - for grocery shopping, medical reasons, exercise or workthis cannot be done from home. Britons have been asked to resist to the temptation of going out because of the sunny  weather  this weekend to help the fight against the outbreak of Covid-.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said sunbathing in public spaces is against the coronavirus social distancing rules. He added thattoo many people flout the lockdown rules, the government will have to take action on allowing exercise.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email With Meghan and Harry officially no longer working members of the royal family, hairstylist George Northwood has finally  been able to confirm that he was the man behind some of the -year-oldaposs most iconic looks.From the undone chignon she wore to her wedding reception in May  to her messy bun, sleek ponytail and loose Cali girl waves.Northwood, who has a hair salon in Fitzrovia revealed in a post on Instagram that he had been working with the Duke and Duchess of Sussex behind the scenes for the last few years. He wrote: It has been an enormous privilege and a lot of fun working with the The Duke and Duchess of Sussex over the past two years.I have enjoyed every minute collaborating with this amazing couple who not only champion small businesses but have taught me so much about ersity, equality and the importance of good mental health.The hairstylist then spoke to British Vogue about what it was really like to work with Meghan and had nothing but nice things to say about the mum-of-one.He explained how he was nervous to meet her, but claims it was all for nothing as they hit it off straight away. “I think I met her in February, around Valentine’s Day , he recalls. She was just like my Calornia girl clients. We hit it off – we immediately spoke the same language.  Northwood continued to say that the pair became very close during the time he worked with her. We went on tour for three weeks to Australia, New Zealand and Tonga etc, and a lot of the time it was just me and her – you have back-to-back engagements, a lot of dferent looks and a full-on schedule, so you become very close in that period. As a hairdresser, you just have a more intimate role, getting someone ready. We made Cali girl hair a bit more formal and had a real laugh.

Just like any other new baby, the little royal was issued a birth certicate with details about when and where he was born, as well as his parentsapos information. All birth certicates are a matter of public record, which means fans got to see it - and it revealed an interesting detail about his mum Meghan Markle. It lists her job description as Princess of the United Kingdom. But this left many fans scratching their heads, wondering why it said princess when Meghanaposs official title is Duchess. While she was given the title the Duchess of Sussex by the Queen on her wedding day, she is also technically a princess, just not in her own name. She is Her Royal Highness Princess Henry of Wales through her husband, Harry. The Duchess of Cambridge also listed princess under the job section part of the form on Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louisaposs birth certicates. Some fans were also surprised to see that the name was listed as Rachel, with many unaware that this is her real name.  But her parents Thomas Markle and Doria Ragland have called her Meghan since birth, and all her of her friends use it rather than Rachel. It was also the name of her popular character in her hit legal drama Suits. Harry is also listed under his real name - Henry - on Archieaposs birth certicate. The document also revealed where Archie was born, despite Meghan and Harry hoping to keep the information private.  The Duchess gave birth at the private Portland Hospital in Westminster - which costs about £,. Portland is a celebrity favourite when it comes to maternity hospitals, with a whole list of A-list patients on the books.

title: nurse says people flouting lockdown
story: NewsNurse says people flouting lockdown rules cuts so deep after seeing people dieThe nurse made the comments after Camden Town  Primrose Hill Police shared a photo showing dozens of people sunbathing or sitting in the sun this weekend - ignoring lockdown rulesShareCommentsByChiara Fiorillo:,  APR NewsPolice officers patrolling Primrose Hill, London " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A nurse said they wish the people flouting lockdown rules could understand the pain felt by coronavirus patients when they die alone - without their loved ones next to them. The nurse, who works for the NHS, made the comments on Twitter after Camden Town  Primrose Hill Police shared a photo showing dozens of people sunbathing this weekend.The police force said they had previously moved on more than  people who were having picnics or were sunbathing at Primrose Hill yesterday. They added that, when they went back to the same spot shortly after, they found a lot of people gathering again.Camden Town  Primrose Hill Police tweeted:#Disappointed is the only word to describe what we found in #PrimroseHill park.A nurse replied: As a nurse working in the NHS this cuts SO deeply.I wish each of those people sat there could hear the sound of a le support machine getting switched off with no one  around. #STAYHOME. It comes after more than , people ignored the  coronavirus  lockdown rules on Saturday afternoon and flocked to Brockwell Park in south London. Lambeth Council announced it would close the park today after advice to stay home was ignored. The authority said in a statement: Despite clear advice, over  people spent today in Brockwell Park, many of them sunbathing or in large groups. This is unacceptable. Unfortunately, the actions of a minority now means that, following police advice, Brockwell Park will be closed tomorrow. #StayHome. We are sorry weaposve had to take this decision. This wouldnapost need to happenpeople followed the clear instructions from the Govt. We are doing this for the wider safety of the public. A minority of people have not followed the guidance - regrettably we have to act. Britons have been asked to stay at home and not be tempted to go out when the weather is warm - as is happening this weekend.Government guidelines to fight the outbreak of the coronavirus allow people to go out only when necessary - to buy food, for medical reasons, for one form of exercise a day or to go to workit cannot be done from home.London Mayor  Sadiq Khan  has warned people not to gather in large groups amid social distancing rules - adding police would step in to stop those breaking the rules.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said sunbathing in public spaces is against the coronavirus social distancing rules.  He added thattoo many people flout the lockdown rules, the government will have to take action on allowing exercise. He told Sky Newsaposs Sophy Ridge On Sunday: The vast majority of people are following the public health advice, which is absolutely critical, and staying at home. But there are a small minority of people who are still not doing that - itaposs quite unbelievable frankly to see that there are some people who are not following the advice. Asked whether sunbathing in public spaces was against the law, he said: Sunbathing is against the rules that have been set out for important public health reasons. He warned those who are flouting the guidance: You are putting othersapos lives at risk and you are putting yourself in harmaposs way. Matt Hancock has warned that the Government may restrict peopleaposs freedom to exercise outdoorsit is clear that people are flouting the rules.
